text: there are many beet salads in this
country and they're wonderful but
they're taxing the ability of our goats
to produce enough cheese for them so I
decided to come up with something
different this is um away my friend the
chef jean-georges Vongerichten taught me
how to do beets and it's really great
you roast them whole unpeeled in
aluminum foil individually if you like
or you can do a bunch in a covered pan
and you roast them for I don't know an
hour or so and when they come out the
tops come off and the skin mostly just
slips right off including that little
root part and the mess is quite minimal
so you can peel these beets whenever you
want stick them in the refrigerator or
even the day before and then heat some
olive oil about half a cup in a skillet
and then 6 or 8 cloves of garlic you
want to get the edge off this garlic you
don't have to cook it all the way
through and you don't the chop it
because it's gonna get pureed so I think
this this sauce with garlic and walnuts
and olive oil and it's a little a little
Balkan a little Greek a Grecian a little
Balkan a little Grecian but I'm adding
some orange juice to it also so it
becomes a little marquee in you can do
this as slowly as you want I'm hurrying
it along a little bit here but not too
bad to me there's nothing more beautiful
than garlic bubbling and oil and then
when it's nearly done halfway done dump
in about 1/2 a cup of walnuts toast them
at the same time a healthy pinch of salt
the walnuts are just trying to get a
little bit of a toasty edge - and the
garlic again just lightly browned and
poofy that's the color we're looking for
walnuts will burn but it's wanting to
keep the heat low you're pretty safe
here like I said a little poufy a little
tender beautifully browned
was the same color as the walnuts cool
it off for a couple of minutes okay
which I did because there's no reason to
get burned here into a little food
processor a little bit of fresh orange
juice see how much we need are you
looking for you're looking for a kind of
salad dressing a consistency here look a
little liquidy but we want the walnuts
to still have some crunch and you know I
was making this with about half this
amount of dressing but it's so good that
I upped it a bit to me this has much
more appeal than goat cheese and you
know we can give the goats a break
to me this cries for something green I
don't think you need the parsley but
that really is gorgeous
the earthiness of the beats is
completely complemented by the walnuts
which have that bitter also earthy
quality the garlic cooked in the oil
which kind of gets sweet but also has
that moodiness that robustness it's just
a lovely combination go three
